bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Office of the Commandant at the Medical Field Service School, January 29, 1941

div1.p: Hench advises that a model of Camp Columbia be corrected. He also requests to have photographs taken of the model.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Office of the Commandant at the Medical Field Service School, January 29, 1941
div1.opener:
January 29, 1941
Office of the Commandant
The Medical Field Service School
Carlisle Barracks
Carlisle, Pa.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
In August and September of last year, I corresponded with
Brigadier General Roger Brooke regarding a model of Camp Columbia, Havana,
Cuba, 1900, which had been for some years in storage at Carlisle Barracks.
I found a photograph of this model in the U. S. Army Medical Museum, Negative
#47033. This photograph is of great importance to me in my attempts to
identify properly the sites in Havana where Walter Reed and colleagues did
their work on yellow fever. The railroad track along remains. General
Brooke in a letter to me dated July 5, 1940, said that the model had not been
set up because they did not know how to fit it properly. I sent them a copy
of the Army Museum's photograph and on my request, General Brooke kindly
had the model set up again and photographed for me, as the Army Museum's
photographs were not very adequate. I have been corresponding with General
Albert E. Truby, retired, who in 1900 was commanding officer at this Post
Hospital at Columbia Barracks. He informs me that the model was obviously
set up wrong in Washington before the Army Museum's photograph was taken and
that it should be re-arranged roughly as I have indicated by repasting the
enclosed photograph.

Dr. Domingo Ramos, Minister of National Defense of the Cuban
government, has asked me to present to him documentary evidence identifying
the former location of this hospital and of Camp Lazear. I expect to visit
Havana in March to present this evidence to him. I would be very grateful
indeed if you could arrange to have the model set up properly according to
the arrangement noted by General Truby, and have it rephotographed for me
from in front and from either side rather than from only on top, as was done
in the enclosed photograph. Whatever expense there is connected with this I
shall be glad to pay. I believe that General Truby will be writing you about
this matter also. The model has assumed such historical importance, being
about the only record we can find available, showing the arrangement of the
buildings, that General Truby has stated his tentative desire to visit Carlisle
sometime in the future to help set it up properly. Since it is impossible for
me to wait until that time I will greatly appreciate the photographs of the
model as rearranged.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
